conclusion: Understanding the problem involves two cars, A and B, traveling on a highway with a given velocity-time graph.
Velocity-time graph has velocity on y-axis and time on x-axis; area under the curve gives displacement.
Car A starts at a lower velocity and increases, while Car B starts at a higher velocity and decreases.
Both curves approach the same velocity at t=t1, but their paths are different.
Consider dividing the area under each curve into smaller parts to estimate displacement.
Both curves might be exponential, affecting the area calculation.
Using average velocity to find displacement: displacement equals average velocity times time.
Calculate average velocity for Car A and Car B by integrating velocity over time.
Consider specific values for velocities and time to understand the problem better.
The shape of the curves (exponential vs. linear) affects displacement calculation.
Assume v_A(t) + v_B(t) = constant = v2 + v1 to explore symmetry in displacements.
Calculate displacement for each car using integration of velocity functions.
Assume exponential functions for v_A(t) and v_B(t) to attempt integration.
